abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project for Maharashtra, India will
            safeguard the tribals' interest in scheduled areas. The
            tribal development plan will have two major objectives: i)
            one related to rural water supply and sanitation delivery
            being attempted through fostering, and empowering
            autonomous, inclusive, equitable and accountable grassroots
            tribal institutions, and ii) institutional strengthening to
            enable the state government in general. The concept of
            self-help and community sharing or resources is ingrained in
            the tribal culture; involving local communities in
            decision-making is part of the tradition. Key issues are
            discussed and conflicts, if any, are resolved in the
            presence of hereditary village head and other elders. The
            project's strategy of decentralization of Village
            Panchayats, and user groups, fits in with the tribal
            socio-economic characteristics and cultural value. At the
            same time, a study on traditional systems of governance
            among tribals will also be completed during the first year
            of the project, with a view to identify
            culturally-appropriate ways of local governance and hence to
            improve tribals' participation and inclusion. The
            tribal development strategy will also be premised on the
            Community Demand Driven (CDD) principles of: autonomy,
            subsidiary, self selection and demand driven participation,
            inclusion and equity, transparency and accountability, and
            cost sharing. Tribals mobilized into groups will be
            capacitated to plan, implement and operate and maintain the
            project activities/facilities.
